docs.lead_paragraph: DENNIS R. BERESFORD, who has been chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board for a turbulent decade, will step down at the end of this month. During his tenure, the board forced companies to begin recognizing the cost of post-retirement benefits while employees are still working. That angered many companies, but is now generally viewed as wise. But the board also underwent the embarrassment of issuing a standard for accounting for income taxes and then, in the face of widespread criticism, backing down and changing the standard.

headline.main: From the Chief Accountant, a Farewell Ledger

docs.abstract: Interview with Dennis R Beresford, retiring chairman of Financial Accounting Standards Board; photo; board's role in compelling companies to recognize cost of retiree benefits noted, as well as Congressional pressure that thwarted proposal to make companies treat value of stock options as expense; Beresford's successor, yet unnamed, will have to be approved by Financial Accounting Foundation, which includes many business executives who are concerned about too-strict standards; appointment must also be approved by SEC chairman Arthur Levitt, who is determined that board remain independent of corporations it regulates (L)
docs.snippet: DENNIS R. BERESFORD, who has been chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board for a turbulent decade, will step down at the end of this month. During his tenure, the board forced companies to begin recognizing the cost of post-retirement...

docs.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Democrats and unaffiliated voters who are willing to declare themselves as Democrats will go to the polls to select a Democratic candidate to challenge Governor Whitman in November. The three candidates are United States Representative Robert E. Andrews of Haddon Heights; State Senator James E. McGreevey, who is also the Mayor of Woodbridge Township, and W. Michael Murphy Jr., a former Morris County prosecutor who lives in Chatham.

headline.main: 3 Democrats Who Would Be Governor: Where They Stand

docs.abstract: Article on Democratic gubernatorial candidates James E McGreevey, Robert E Andrews and W Michael Murphy Jr notes their positions on some issues that affect New Jersey; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Clinton Administration officials say they will soon propose expanding Medicaid to cover low-income people who have been infected with the virus that causes AIDS but do not show any symptoms of the disease. The Government could then pay for potent, costly drugs that block development of AIDS.

headline.main: Medicaid May Be Extended to Early Treatment of AIDS

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration officials say they will soon propose expanding Medicaid to cover low-income people who have been infected with HIV virus that causes AIDS but do not show any symptoms of disease; Government could then pay for potent, costly drugs that block development of AIDS (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The General Assembly sent a bill yesterday requiring a 48-hour minimum hospital stay for women who have mastectomies to Gov. John G. Rowland, who is expected to sign it. House members unanimously adopted the bill, while expressing outrage that it was even necessary to adopt legislation ''body part by body part.'' The bill, already passed by the Senate, allows doctors and patients to determine whether a woman should spend 48 hours in the hospital. Connecticut's new managed care law, passed this session, gives doctors the right to ask for a longer hospital stay and gives patients the right to appeal medical decisions made by managed care companies. Legislators said they hoped that law would end the need for bills like this one.

headline.main: Mastectomy Bill Is Sent to Governor

docs.abstract: Connecticut Gov John Rowland is expected to sign bill mandating 48-hour minimum hospital stay for women who undergo mastectomies (S)
